title: Global Stocks Fall on China Trade Data
text:
By Chiara Albanese and Riva Gold
Global stocks fell Tuesday after the latest evidence that China's economy is slowing.
U.S. stocks opened lower, tracking losses in Europe and Asia, after data showed that China's exports dropped 3.7% from a year earlier in September.
Weak economic data from China fueled fears that the country's third-quarter growth data, due next week, would fall below Beijing's target, helping to stall the global stock rally that kicked off last week.
The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 80 points, or 0.5%, to 17051 in early trade, while the S&P 500 declined 0.4% and the Nasdaq Composite was 0.6% lower.
The Stoxx Europe 600 was 1.6% lower midafternoon, dragged lower by mining stocks on the index, which would be particularly vulnerable to a slowdown in the world second-largest economy.
Earlier, Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index closed 0.6% lower and Japan's Nikkei Stock Average fell 1.1% as it reopened after a holiday. The Shanghai Composite Index closed 0.2% up.
"China and emerging markets growth have been slowing since 2011. But will this impact U.S. and European growth? This is a key concern for investors," said Nick Nelson, head of global equity strategy at UBS in London.
While he doesn't think this would be the case, a few months of strong economic data will be needed to ease investors' concerns.
"Until then, markets are going to remain volatile," he said.
Driven by a rally in consumer and health-care stocks, the Dow Jones Industrial Average climbed for a seventh consecutive day on Monday.
The pound fell 0.8% against the dollar after data showed that U.K. consumer prices fell 0.1% in September, a fresh sign that expansionary policies by central bankers around the world are failing to stoke inflation. Inflation has been close to zero throughout the year. The pound was recently trading at $1.5216 against the buck.
Economists at BNP Paribas have pushed back expectations for an interest rate rise by the Bank of England from February 2016 to May. "However, the market isn't pricing in a full rate hike until the first quarter of 2017," they said in a note.
The euro was 0.3% higher at $1.1393 against the dollar, having earlier traded above $1.14.
In corporate news, SABMiller PLC's board agreed on the key terms of a sweetened takeover offer by Anheuser-Busch InBev NV, valuing it at GBP68 billion ($104.36 billion). The move sets the stage for the world's two largest brewers to combine after weeks of back and forth. SABMiller shares rose 9.3%, while AB InBev shares were up 1.6%.
In commodities, Brent crude was at $50.21 a barrel, mostly flat on the day. Gold was 0.3% lower at $1,161.60 an ounce after rising sharply on Monday.
Write to Chiara Albanese at chiara.albanese@wsj.com and Riva Gold at riva.gold@wsj.com
(END) Dow Jones Newswires
